Luo and F. Zhao contributed equally to this study. Gas-solid acetylene dimerization has provided a facile and effective way to product MVA under mild conditions, whereas the copper-based catalysts using cuprous chloride as precursor are generally not regarded as ideal candidates, owing to its good ability for reaction with acetylene to produce explosive cuprous acetylide, and needs to help with other solvents and cosolvents for above process. Herein, we proposed a CuCl2/AC catalyst with CuCl2·H2O as the precursor. The reaction and deactivation mechanism of CuCl2/AC catalyst were investigated through experimental characterization and DFT calculation. Theoretical calculations revealed that the Cu(II) reduction, Cl dissociation (TS-1) was the rate-limiting step in CuCl2/AC catalyst for acetylene dimerization reaction, and the acetylene dimerization reaction prefers to the main-reaction path of generating MVA. Moreover, ICP analysis indicated that catalyst deactivation during acetylene dimerization could be attributed to active component loss. This work provides new theoretical insights into gas-solid acetylene dimerization. Graphical abstract The catalytic cycle involves the adsorption of C2H2, activation of C2H2 on copper atoms, reduction of Cu(II), dissociation of Cl, addition of acetylene, transfer of hydrogen from HCl and desorption of products. The Cu(II) reduction, Cl dissociation (TS-1) was the rate-limiting step in CuCl2/AC catalyst for acetylene dimerization reaction, with the active center being the CuCl complex and the acetylene dimerization reaction prefers to the main-reaction path of generating MVA. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Acetylene dimerization CuCl2-based catalysts Catalytic mechanism DFT calculation Catalyst deactivation Data availability The data that has been used is confidential. 1 Introduction As one of the seven primary synthetic rubber materials, chloroprene rubber (CR) finds extensive application in national defense, transportation, construction industry and other fields owing to its exceptional mechanical properties and chemical stability [1–5]. The acetylene dimerization process for producing monovinylacetylene (MVA) is a crucial step in CR production that is widely employed in coal-rich regions [6]. Moreover, MVA is also a crucial intermediate in the synthesis of significant chemical products such as benzene, styrene, chloroprene and butanedione [7]. With the escalating price of oil, acetylene dimerization could possibly serve as a viable source of CR and other materials, making efficient production of MVA incredibly significant. A Nieuwland catalyst (NC), consisting of CuCl and KCl or NH4Cl in aqueous acidic solution, has been widely utilized for industrial-scale acetylene dimerization. M. Briant et al. employed the helium nanodroplet separation technique (HENDI) to investigate the antisymmetric CH stretching of two acetylene molecules during dimerization [8]. Dai et al. studied the adsorption of acetylene molecules on CuCl (111) surface using density functional theory (DFT) method in quantum chemistry and found that the adsorption at the Top-Cu position is relatively stable, while the adsorption on CuCl is physical adsorption [9]. Liu et al. determined the value of n for the catalytic anion CunCln +1 in both NC and anhydrous catalyst [10]. Tachiyama et al. discovered that the exchange between the protons of acetylene and deuterium atoms in water takes place faster than the dimerization reaction [11,12]. Shunichi et al. first reported the mechanism of NC for acetylene dimerization and found efficient H/D exchange between acetylene and protons [13]. Furthermore, investigations have been conducted on the impact of solvent effect [14–16], the NC structure [10,17], ligand modification [18–20], kinetics [21], and metal additives on gas-liquid C2H2 dimerization with NC [22–25]. These modifications have significantly improved the process of acetylene dimerization. However, the NC has always suffered from low acetylene conversion rates, poor selectivity for vinylacetylene, and high levels of polymerization products. Therefore, there is an urgent need for more stable and high-performance catalysts to improve acetylene dimerization. So as to solve this problem, some researchers have turned their attention to the gas-solid reaction process, which offers superior contact opportunities between the alkyne and the catalytic system in comparison to the gas-liquid reaction. Recently, Li et al. [26]. reported a gas-solid acetylene dimerization reaction using Cu/AC catalysts prepared via an impregnation technique with CuCl as the precursor and DMF and 1,4-Dioxane as solvents, along with ethylamine hydrochloride as cosolvent. Additionally, to improve the catalytic performance, Cu(II)Cu(I)/AC catalysts were prepared and it was found that adding Cu(II) could inhibit loss of Cu species while increasing initial activity and dispersion of the catalysts [23]. Furthermore, the nitrogen-modified AC can effectively enhance the interaction between copper species and the support, thereby promoting catalytic performance [27]. Nevertheless, since the invention of NC, CuCl remains the catalyst precursor for acetylene dimerization reaction, resulting in poor contact efficiency between active species and reactant acetylene due to its low solubility. Many efforts have been made to maximize the solubility of CuCl catalysts by using organic solvents or co-solvents, and to improve the efficiency of acetylene contact with the catalyst by switching from gas-liquid to gas-solid. However, environmental damage occurs during catalyst preparation and recycling treatment. Therefore, we aim to identify a more environmentally friendly and cost-effective alternative to CuCl as a precursor for the preparation of metal-loaded catalysts. In this study, we examined various metal active components and determined that the catalyst prepared with CuCl2·H2O as the precursor exhibited superior performance in acetylene dimerization. Additionally, we conducted a comprehensive investigation into the mechanism of acetylene dimerization reaction on CuCl2/AC catalysts using quantum chemical density functional theory (DFT), and analyzed the factors contributing to catalyst deactivation through XPS, XRD, TEM, TG, BET and ICP. This mechanism provides novel insights for designing efficient catalysts and their further applications in gas-solid acetylene dimerization reactions. 2 Experimental 2.1 Reagents The coconut-shell-activated carbon (AC, 60–80 mesh) was procured from S. S. activated carbon industry science and technology Co., Ltd. copper (II) chloride dihydrate (CuCl2·2H2O, 98%), silver nitrate (AgNO3), cerium (III) chloride hexahydrate (CeCl3·7H2O), zinc chloride (ZnCl2), cobalt chloride (CoCl2·6H2O), zirconium tetrachloride (ZrCl4), lanthanum (III) chloride (LaCl3), ruthenium (III) chloride hydrate (RuCl3), nickel (II) chloride hexahydrate (NiCl2·6H2O), cupric acetate monohydrate (Cu(CH3COO)2·H2O), cuprous chloride (CuCl), cupric sulfate (CuSO₄), cupric nitrate (Cu(NO3)2), cupric carbonate basic Cu₂(OH)₂CO₃) were purchased from Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Co., Ltd. All commercially accessible materials were of analytical grade and required no purification when used. 2.2 Preparation Catalyst Synthesis: For each preparation, precursor (e.g., CuCl2·2H2O, AgNO3, CeCl3·7H2O, ZnCl2, CoCl2·6H2O, ZrCl4, LaCl3, RuCl3, NiCl2·6H2O) was dissolved in 10 mL of water solution and stirred at room temperature until fully dissolved. The concentration of each metal solution was chosen in order to obtain a theoretical metal content of approximately 10 wt% in the catalysts. Then, 4 g of coconut-shell-activated carbon was added to the mixture which was subsequently placed in a sealed beaker and magnetically stirred for another 12 h at 323 K. Subsequently, the mixture was dried overnight at 373 K to prepare the monometallic catalyst (e.g., CuCl2/AC, AgNO3/AC, CeCl3/AC, ZnCl2/AC, CoCl2/AC, ZrCl4/AC, LaCl3/AC, RuCl3/AC, NiCl2/AC). Similarly procedure prepared were Cu-based catalysts (e.g., Cu(CH3COO)2/AC, CuCl/AC, Cu(NO3)2/AC, CuSO4/AC, CuCO3·Cu(OH)2/AC, CuCl2/AC). In this experimental study, the relevant catalysts prepared with a metal load of 10.0 wt% were used for catalyst characterization. 2.3 Characterization methods X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements were conducted using a Rigaku Ultima IV diffraction spectrometer from Japan, equipped with monochromatized Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.15406 nm), and operated in the 2θ scan range of 10° to 80°. The catalysts underwent inspection via X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) at room temperature, utilizing a monochromatic Al Ka X-ray source (1486.6 eV) and a thermal Thermo Scientific K-Alpha spectrometer (Waltham, MA, USA). All binding energies were determined by the C 1 s peak (BE = 284.8 eV) as a standard. Thermo Avantage software was used to determine the elemental compositions based on the peak areas and sensitivity factor from the C 1 s, N 1 s, O 1 s, and Cu 2p peaks. The quantity of metallic elements in the catalysts was determined using Inductively Coupled Plasma Atomic Emission Spectroscopy (ICP-OES, Agilent 5110). Images taken using a Titan G260–300 electron microscope operating at 200 kV are transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images. Subsequently, the particle sizes were determined through TEM image analysis using nano measurer software. The TA TGA5500 thermogravimetric analyser (TG) from the United States was utilized to measure the amount of coke deposition on the used catalysts under an air atmosphere. The temperature was increased from 25 to 800 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C/min. On a Micromeritics ASAP-2460 device, the BET surface region, pore volumes, and pore diameter of the catalysts were measured (Norcross, GA, USA). The specific surface area (SBET) was calculated using the multi-point Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method. 2.4 Catalytic activity test Catalyst tests were carried out in a continuous fixed-bed flow microreactor (i.d., 10 mm) under atmospheric pressure conditions (see Fig. 1 ). Approximately 2 mL of the catalyst sample was loaded into the tubular reactor, which was then positioned at the middle of the reactor furnace. Before the reaction, a nitrogen purge pipeline was employed for 30 min to remove moisture and air from the pipeline. At the same time, the temperature was heated to 100 °C at a rate of 5 °C/min. Then, to obtain an acetylene gas hourly space velocity (C2H2 GHSV) value of 120 h − 1 (C2H2: 3.6 mL/min), acetylene (gas, 98.0%) was supplied into a filter via calibrated mass flow controllers and into a fixed-bed microreactor containing the catalysts. After that, the gas mixture enters a water-filled scrubber. Finally, the gas mixture was injected into a gas chromatograph (Shimadzu, GC-2014C, GDX-301, and a flame ionization detector) every 20 min during the experiment for compositional analysis. The conversion of acetylene (X) and selectivity of MVA (S) were estimated for each analysis after a steady operation for 1.5 h using the normalized area normalization technique. The following equation served as the definition for the terms X and S, X = [ ( 2 α 2 + 2 α 3 + 3 α 4 ) / ( α 1 + 2 α 2 + 2 α 3 + 3 α 4 ) × 100 % S = [ 2 α 2 / ( α 1 + 2 α 2 + 2 α 3 + 3 α 4 ) × 100 % where α1, α2, α3, and α4 stand for the volume fractions of C2H2, MVA, 2‑chloro-1,3-butadiene, and 1,5-hexadien-3‑yne (DVA), respectively, in the gas products. 2.5 Calculation details All calculations were conducted using Guassian09 software package with the hybrid B3LYP density functional method [28]. To ensure accuracy results, a van der Waals energy correction was applied utilizing parameters defined by Grimme et al. [29]. The 6–31+G** basis set was adopted for all atoms except for Cu described with the LANL2DZ pseudopotential basis set. All stationary points (i.e., reactants (Re), adsorptions (Ads), products (Pr), intermediates (Is), transition states (Ts) and desorption states (De-ads) were calculated at the same level. The various stationary points were identified through harmonic vibrational frequency analyzation to be whether a minimum (no imaginary frequency) or a transition structure (only one imaginary frequency). The total energies were corrected for zero-point energies (ZPE), which was obtained from the frequency calculations. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic performance for gas−solid acetylene dimerization Upgrading traditional industries with advanced, applicable, energy-saving, low-carbon and environmental protection technologies is the core task of accelerating the establishment of an innovative, green and low-carbon industrial system. Therefore, it is necessary to develop new catalysts for acetylene dimerization that are energy-saving and environmentally friendly in order to overcome the shortcomings of CuCl system catalysts (Figure S1). As shown in Figs. 2 (a)-(c), the catalytic performance of nine catalysts was assessed for gas-solid dimerization acetylene to investigate the impact of different active substances. The experimental results revealed that copper-based catalyst exhibited superior catalytic activity among all tested catalysts. Additionally, we conducted further research on the impact of copper compounds on the catalytic performance of Cu-based catalysts and determined that the highest activity was achieved when utilizing CuCl2 as the active species (Figs. 2(d)-(f)). However, the low conversion, selectivity and rapid deactivation pose significant challenges. Consequently, experimental characterization and DFT calculations were utilized to investigate the reaction mechanism and deactivation pathway of CuCl2/AC catalysts. The insights gained from this study will deepen our understanding of the activity, stability and reaction mechanisms of Cu-based catalysts. If significant improvements can be made to the activity and stability of copper-based catalysts, it will have a profound impact on the MVA industry. 3.2 Reaction mechanisms of acetylene dimerization over Cu-based /AC catalyst It is important to understand the structure of Cu catalytic center in CuCl2/AC catalyst and the structure of intermediate products formed with acetylene for the preparation of high-performance copper-based catalyst. DFT simulations were employed to reveal the reaction pathway of CuCl2/AC-catalyzed acetylene dimerization, which provides insights into its activity, stability, and reaction mechanism. The energy pathways of the reaction initiated by C2H2 adsorption on the active Cu center of CuCl2 are illustrated in Fig. 3 . The corresponding structures for various stationary points identified on the potential energy surface are illustrated in Fig. 4 , while Table 1 displays the imaginary frequencies and energy barriers. At the beginning of this reaction, the C2H2 bonding with the Cu sites and transferred its π electrons to the catalyst to form a π-ligand structure (Ads). Then the adsorption structure was converted into the first intermediate state (Is-1) underwent a transition state (Ts-1) with an energy barrier of 27.04 kcal/mol. The vibrational analysis of the Ts-1 structure yielded only one imaginary frequency ( ν ¯ = − 798.46 c m − 1 ) , which corresponds to the stretching movement of the H atom and dissociation of Cl. In the process of Ads to Is-1, the dissociated H ion from activated C2H2 molecular was combined with one of the Cl atoms lost by CuCl2 to form the Is-1 state involves C2HCuCl δ complex and HCl. Then, the δ complex adsorbed the second C2H2 molecule to form Is-2 state through an exothermic process. Similarly, the adsorbed C2H2 molecule was activated to the second transition state (Ts-2, ( ν ¯ = − 421.61 c m − 1 ) ) to form the intermediate of C2H2-C2H-CuCl complex (Is-3) with an energy barrier of 17.82 kcal/mol. Next, the hydrogen ion on the C3 atom of the above-mentioned complex dissociated and transferred to the C1 atom via Ts-3 ( ν ¯ = − 941.77 c m − 1 , E a = 14.80 k c a l / m o l ) to form the C2H-C2H2-CuCl complex (Is-4). In the last transition state Ts-4 ( ν ¯ = − 548.87 c m − 1 , E a = 2.41 k c a l / m o l ) , a hydrogen transfer from the HCl and bonding with the C1 atom while the shed Cl atom connected to Cu to form the desorbed state De-ads-1 of MVA. It is worth noting that the hydrogen-migration progress simultaneously with the cleavage of the HCl bond and the formation of a new Cu-Cl bond through transition states Ts-4. Finally, the MVA is desorbed from the catalyst and flows out of the catalytic system with the reaction gas, and CuCl2 continues to catalyze the acetylene dimerization reaction. In the whole catalytic process, the highest energy barrier appeared in the formation of Ts-1, which means that the Cu(II) reduction, Cl dissociation was the rate-limiting step in CuCl2 catalyze for acetylene dimerization reaction. For the generation mechanism of by-product DVA (Fig. 5 ), it starts with the absorbing of a free acetylene on C2H2-C2H-CuCl complex to form Is-5. The adsorbed C2H2 molecule was activated and showed a transition state Ts-5 ( ν ¯ = − 521.16 c m − 1 ) with a higher energy barrier of 15.33 kcal/mol to form the intermediate of Is-6 (in Table 2 ). Then, Is-7 state generated after Is-6 state showed a second transition state Ts-6 ( ν ¯ = − 2123.6 c m − 1 , E a = 31.54 k c a l / m o l ) with the hydrogen ion at C4 atom transferred to C6 atom. At the Ts-7 state ( ν ¯ = − 460.16 c m − 1 , E a = 6.28 k c a l / m o l ) , hydrogen-migration occurs concomitantly with the cleavage of the HCl bond and the formation of the C2H3-C2-C2H-CuCl complex while the shed Cl connect with Cu to form the desorbed De-ads-2 state of DVA, and then the DVA desorbed to form free DVA and CuCl2. By comparing the energy barrier, the hydrogen ion at C4 atom transferred to C6 atom in Ts-6 became the rate-limiting step in the side-reaction. Owing to the higher energy barrier in Ts-5 than in Ts-4, the acetylene dimerization reaction prefers to the main-reaction path of generating MVA. 3.3 Catalyst physical characteristics When the reaction proceeds along the main reaction pathway, the catalyst still maintains the linear structure of CuCl2 even after completion of the reaction, and its activity remains unaltered. However, the intermediate product HCl formed during the reaction and the C2HCuCl δ complex structure combine to produce vinyl chloride, while the CuCl2 catalyst is permanently deactivated through reduction to CuCl or zero-valent copper. As shown in Figure S2, the similar reaction mechanism starting from CuCl as the catalyst. Due to the formation of intermediate product HCl, the CuCl molecular converted to neutral Cu atom and generated undesirable intermediates with ultrahigh energy barrier. This results in a decline in the activity and selectivity of CuCl2/AC catalyst. To investigate the presence of copper atoms in the catalyst before and after deactivation, Auger spectrum analysis was conducted for a reaction time of 10 h. The Cu 2p3/2 core level XPS spectra of fresh and used CuCl2/AC are presented in Figs. 6 a, wherein the peaks have been deconvoluted to identify different copper species and their respective quantities. The peak at 932–935.5 eV has been bifurcated by curve fitting, with the first major peak positioned at 935.0 ± 0.1 eV and a second minor peak located at 932.7 ± 0.1 eV. The main peak with higher energy (at 935.0 eV) can be attributed to Cu(II), while the minor peak at 932.7 eV is indicative of the presence of Cu(I) or metallic Cu(0) species [30]. As shown in Fig. 6a and b, the ratio of Cu(II)/Cu(I) clearly changes in fresh and used CuCl2/AC catalysts, which might explain the part of Cu(II) of CuCl2 /AC catalyst was reduced to Cu(I) or Cu(0) by acetylene during reaction progresses. The difference in binding energies between Cu(I) and Cu(0) species is determined by the Cu LMM Auger spectra. The peak at 910.5 eV in the Cu LMM XAES spectra of the catalysts shows a distinct transition state of the Cu LMM spectrum, while peaks for Cu(0) and Cu(II) and Cu(I) were seen at around 918.6 eV and 915.5 eV, respectively (Fig. 6(b)). The relative contents of Cu(II), Cu(I), and Cu(0) are shown in Figure 6(c) and (d) based on the respective deconvoluted peak area [23]. It is evident from Figure 6(c) and (d) that the ratio of Cu(II) to Cu(I) undergoes a significant change, which may account for the decline in acetylene conversion during the reaction progression. 3.4 Deactivation catalyst characterization analysis TEM technology was used to explore the dispersion state of copper components in the Cu-based catalyst, and the TEM images are shown in Figs. 7 . From Fig. 7(a), it can be seen that the copper species in the fresh CuCl2/AC catalyst particles are irregular, round, and about 20–25 nm in size. Furthermore, the energy-dispersive X-ray (EDX) elemental mapping of fresh CuCl2/AC and used CuCl2/AC catalysts in Fig. 7(a) and (b) revealed the presence of Cl, O, and Cu in the fresh CuCl2/AC catalyst with a homogeneous distribution [31,32]. However, severe aggregation of Cu species was observed in the used catalyst indicating that active species aggregation is one of the causes for catalyst deactivation. We also performed XRD analysis on the sample catalyst to investigate the potential active species of CuCl2/AC catalysts. The diffraction peaks observed in Fig. 8 (a) at 24.4° and 43.7°, corresponding to (0 0 2) and (1 0 1) planes respectively, were identified as those of the AC support. For the CuCl2/AC catalyst, diffraction peaks at 2θ of 16.29°, 22°, 28.95° and 34.01° were detected for the eriochalcite syn CuCl2(H2O)2 became detectable based on the JCPDS (72–0572) file data before reaction due to the agglomeration of eriochalcite syn species [33]. The diffraction peaks of CuCl (JCPDS 06–0344) were observed in used (after 600 min) CuCl2 /AC catalysts, with peak 2θ values at 28.49°, 32.92°, 47.43° and 56.28° respectively; However, the adsorption of acetylene molecules on the surface of CuCl (1 1 1) was physical [9]. XRD results indicate that acetylene reduces CuCl2 to CuCl and aggregation is one of the main reasons for catalyst deactivation, which is consistent with XPS observations [34]. Thermo Gravimetric (TG) was employed to investigate the carbon deposition of fresh and used CuCl2/AC catalysts. As shown in Fig. 8(b), both fresh and used CuCl2/AC catalysts displayed three distinct weight loss stages, with a slight decrease in weight observed before 150 °C due to the desorption of adsorbed water. The weight loss observed in the temperature range of 150–272 °C can be attributed to the combustion of carbonaceous deposits on the catalyst surface, while the rapid weight loss above 272 °C is primarily due to the oxidation of AC support. It is noteworthy that the weight loss within 150–272 °C reflects directly on the extent of coking deposition on the catalyst surface. [35,36]. It is evident that the weight loss of CuCl2/AC after use was 7.5% within the temperature range of 150–272 °C, whereas it was only 3.0% for fresh CuCl2/AC. As a result, the carbon deposition on the catalyst surface for used CuCl2/AC is approximately 4.5%, based on coke deposition calculation over the same temperature interval. The impact of acetylene dimerization on pore volume, pore diameter and BET surface area of CuCl2/AC catalysts are shown in Fig. 9 (a) and Table 3 . All samples exhibit reversible Langmuir type IV isotherms with H1-type hysteresis loops [37], indicating that the CuCl2/AC catalysts maintain large-pore mesopores. After the loading of active copper chloride species, the surface areas (SBET) of AC rapidly dropped from 1043.85 to 157.34 m2·g − 1. This result was due to the active copper species being heavily loaded, filling or blocking part of the pores of the activated carbon. After a reaction time of 10 h, the used catalysts SBET (28.70 m2·g − 1) and total pore volumes (V) were lower than those of the fresh catalysts. However, the isotherms of used CuCl2/AC samples differed significantly from those of fresh CuCl2/AC catalysts, indicating that the acetylene dimerization had a noticeable effect on the CuCl2/AC catalysts. This may be attributed to the deposition of carbon during the reaction, which is consistent with the TG data. Combining TEM and BET data, it was determined that low catalytic activity resulted from inadequate dispersion of active components and blockage of carrier voids. The copper loss pathway in the CuCl2/AC catalyst was investigated using ICP-OES, FT-IR and DFT techniques. As shown in Table 4 , the total copper content of both fresh and used CuCl2/AC catalysts was measured by ICP-OES. Before the reaction, the Cu loading in the CuCl2/AC catalysts was 12.75%. After a reaction time of 10 h, this value decreased to 5.77%. The data in Table 4 clearly indicate that there is a significant difference between these two values, with a loss rate of copper for CuCl2/AC being calculated as high as 54.75%. Therefore, it can be concluded that the primary reason for catalyst deactivation is due to copper loss. Importantly, in order to explore the Cu species loss, the Cu species content in the H2O solution of gas wash bottle was detected, and the result was listed in Table 4. It is showed that Cu species were detected in the H2O solution of gas wash bottle, which might be carried by the gas mixture from the reaction system. Fig. 9b indicates that the breath vibration frequencies of CO have undergone a shift from 1097.4 cm−1 in sample gas/1,4-Dioxacyclohexane to 1076.5 cm−1 in gas mixture/1,4-Dioxacyclohexane [38]. These effects are likely attributed to the alteration of electronic cloud in the CO, implying the formation of Cu(II)-O coordination. The IR spectra of the gas mixture/1,4-Dioxacyclohexane sample exhibit a hydrocarbon bending vibration peak at 615.3 cm−1 and display the characteristic spectrum associated with alkyne functionality at 1255.6 cm−1 [39]. At the same time, the DFT results show that the intermediates of C2HCuCl δ complex and C2H2 C2HCuCl complex can be formed during the acetylene dimerization. In conjunction with ICP-OES, FT-IR, and DFT data, it was ascertained that Cu species in the reaction system could potentially be lost in the form of C2HCuCl δ complex and C2H2 C2HCuCl complexes along with the reaction gas mixture. Conclusions In summary, we propose a monometallic Cu-based catalyst for acetylene dimerization that differs from the commonly applied NC. The catalyst employs CuCl2 as an active component, water as a solvent, and AC as a catalyst carrier. It offers the advantages of simple preparation methods for the catalyst, readily available raw materials, and environmental friendliness. Meanwhile, the catalytic mechanistic details of CuCl2/AC-catalyzed acetylene dimerization reaction were calculated using DFT. The catalytic cycle involves the adsorption of C2H2, activation of C2H2 on copper atoms, reduction of Cu(II), dissociation of Cl, addition of acetylene, transfer of hydrogen from HCl and desorption of products. The rate-determining step for the CuCl2/AC catalyst was the reduction of Cu(II) and dissociation of Cl (Ts-1), with the active center being the acetylene CuCl complex. In addition, ICP, TEM, XRD, TG and BET analyses revealed that the deactivation of catalysts in acetylene dimerization is caused by the loss of active components, aggregation of active copper species and deposition of carbonaceous material on the catalyst. This work provides new theoretical insights into gas-solid acetylene dimerization, and serves as a valuable reference for designing more efficient Cu-based catalysts that can be applied to other acetylene reactions. coredata.dc:description: Gas-solid acetylene dimerization has provided a facile and effective way to product MVA under mild conditions, whereas the copper-based catalysts using cuprous chloride as precursor are generally not regarded as ideal candidates, owing to its good ability for reaction with acetylene to produce explosive cuprous acetylide, and needs to help with other solvents and cosolvents for above process. Herein, we proposed a CuCl2/AC catalyst with CuCl2·H2O as the precursor. The reaction and deactivation mechanism of CuCl2/AC catalyst were investigated through experimental characterization and DFT calculation. Theoretical calculations revealed that the Cu(II) reduction, Cl dissociation (TS-1) was the rate-limiting step in CuCl2/AC catalyst for acetylene dimerization reaction, and the acetylene dimerization reaction prefers to the main-reaction path of generating MVA. Moreover, ICP analysis indicated that catalyst deactivation during acetylene dimerization could be attributed to active component loss. This work provides new theoretical insights into gas-solid acetylene dimerization.
coredata.dc:title: Reactive and deactivation mechanisms of acetylene dimerization on CuCl2/AC catalyst
